reviewText:
Premise: I really wanted to like this game, and I still do to some extent. Bear with me this might be a long text (if you're bored just skip to tl;dr down below).

I have bought the game on 2 December 2015, the devs have the tendency to publish on historical dates (December 2 is the date of the battle of Austerlitz) adn they did it again with May 5 (Napoleon's death) although it was delayed a bit. This may seem a trivial thing BUT they release this game in an unplayable state regardless just because the date was historical.
I love Napoleon and his Age a lot, every time I hear about the Napoleonic era I get proud like it was a tale about my grandfather. I have bought and played every single napoleonic game in existence, board game and \ or card game. So it came natural for me to buy this one, despite the fact that Pride of Nations, another title by AgeoD, didnt suit my taste, but then again, that was probably because it was very complicated and hard to get into. The devs have a history of good games on their shoulders, despite being in very small number. I was confident that historical accuracy was their aim and they would deliver, but the game was absolutely broken.

Foundamental elements like the UI, the buttons, the saving system, everything was either not functioning, or missing, or prone to crash every turn. It seems that the Steam release is still under development, because the last patch didnt fix all the bugs and spelling errors and silly scripts that undermine the game. I have complained on the devs forum and it was told to me that they are a small team and they have a very tiny budget". Well then
date: that excuse doesnt work: let me tell you this: if you know that you are a small dev team
recommended: and you are not confident in a product of this magnitude being released
hoursPlayed: because you know that you need more time and tests to run
voteText: then dont release the game in a "beta" state. It is as simple as that. Instead
helpfulPercent: players are treated as beta testers and even now the team is asking for feedback and support because there are a ton more people like me that had problems in the past and still do to this day. In my case
votesHelpful: the game crashes at random times between turns very early on
votesTotal: or gives strange error messages in the option menu. The frame rate is atrocious
votesFunny: even for an i7 CPU; in the text messages which are describing currency in the game
column16: sometimes to "pounds".\nI just dont understand the developers' behaviour. Quite frankly
column17: AgeoD needs to pull their stuff together and get it done properly
column18: and learn from their mistakes. To the potential buyers I say: dont buy this game in its current state. Wait several months until you are absolutely sure that the product is worth the price. I paid 40 Eur to be a betatester
column19: dont make the same mistake.\n\ntl;dr - The game is still an "under construction" beta and if you buy it you get to be a beta tester with an empty wallet. Wait for this game to be finished properly. Also
column20: it is apparent that this is not a finished game as the devs didnt even bother to get rid of the debug log."

reviewText:
I bought this prior to Steam, so I will say I have gone through a lot of patches. I had some CTDs which were solved because I  wanted to play the game a lot. So I asked on the Matrix and Ageod tech-support forums and they provided me with things I could do to stop it crashing. It worked and since that time the game has not crashed once. So before you keyboard away stating that the game is buggy and dismissing it from those reasons, maybe it could be in your interests to actually go to the Matrix Games or Slitherine or Ageod Forums and ask for advice, because you will get answers on how to fix the game. Right.

WoN is a true Grand Strategy title of the Napoleonic Wars starting from 1805 till Waterloo in 1815. Any Ageod veteran will become familiar with the way the game plays; much complexity with creating Armies, Corps, finding the right leader for command. The map is gigantic, a very attractive map of Europe, with 'boxes' on the side so you can pull in war materials, money etc, from America or India with your Merchant Fleets, building Privateers for raiding, etc. Not a big part of the game, but an interesting aspect to it nonetheless. Beware - do not expect an easy game. If you are new to these type of wargames then be prepared for a learning curve, quite steep, but the rewards are great just spending time learning the game. If you are a fan of anything Napoleonic and want something with the history, the attention to detail, impressive gameplay (I advise play France first) and just a 'feel' for the times, then this game will not disappoint in any way.

Good game.

reviewText: Been playing for a while since earlier Matrix release I couldn't observe crash problems. Our long campaign PBEM game did go without problems.  I don't think any game currently could match operational scale in the campaign level achieved in the subject as this game. It is surely ambitious game. Just as it needs patience and to be played with good players for better enjoyment factor. Infantry models, events all there to find in a Napoleonic game.

reviewText: Quite simply the most elegant simulation of the multi-coalition wars in the period 1805-15.  Avoids the problem of many games of having constant war with all the allies vs France as diplomacy plays a major role.  Critical states such as Austria and Russia have other interests than just war with France - in particular both can gain a lot by attacking the Ottomans.\n\nFor the French, winning early victories is relatively easy, bringing down Perfidious Albion much harder and sooner or later Britain's squabbling allies will start to co-operate.  .... And it is a very long way to Moscow
voteText: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Just registered my steam key for Wars of Napoleon, but have been playing it since it came out in december 2015.  Great game, cannot recommend it enough, due to its depth, scope, GUI, graphics.

The CTDs mentioned by others can be ameliorated by changing game settings at startup, doing regular saves, getting the latest patch - visit the AGEOD forum for the game, where there are lots of tips on this.  It's a resource intensive game, so minimize that where possible, for instance not loading all the map at startup.

The game is absolutely playable - I have many hours with it, before I got it registered on Steam  It has a learning curve.  I note most of the 'no' recommendations on Steam are from people who have played the game just fractions of an hour, or so.  Give the game some time.  Do the tutorials.

This is the ultimate Napoleonic era game, and if you'll invest some time in it, you won't regret it.
voteText: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Really enjoy the game, I brought it direct from AGEOD when it first came out. It is the most detailed Napoleonic pc game I have played and the map looks brilliant too! The campaign is a monster so don't expect to be able to get through a full game too quickly! Don't be put off by the negative reviews as AGEOD are a great company when it comes to supporting and improving their games.
voteText: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Being a history buff and an avid player of wargames, both the old boardgames and the PC types, the release of Wars of Napoleon (WoN) is extremely welcomed.

The artwork is beautiful, and the overall look of the game is superb.

It is a detailed game with a steep learning curve, even with a complete reading of the manual and watching the tuturial videos. Grasping gameplay can be slow and sometimes frustrating, however, the designers (and the fans) of the game are very responsive to questions on the forums and will happily answer any questions, both technical/gameplay.

With that said, sometimes there will be CTDs, but they are few and far between, make sure to save your game before processing a turn.

It's a great game and will keep the player absorbed and engaged, much like Napoleon himself, as you try to bring your enemy to heel.

Rating: 8/10
voteText: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful

reviewText: An absolutely awesome addition to the AGEOD's catalogue. Fight as Napoleon,  or his rivals in a majestic battle for control of Europe! Ageods games have more information/tooltips than any historical game I know of. Highly recommended 9/10. Here is some gameplay to give you an idea of what to expect.\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qQduRdBkeCE

reviewText: I've owned the game since its initial release in December 2015, and have thoroughly enjoyed the game so far.  As it stands, it is a highly playable recreation of the Napoleonic era at the grand strategic and operational level, with an added political diplomatic dimension.\n\nI have mainly played as France, so I cannot comment as to the other nations' gameplay, and I have found the experience to be enjoyable and credible. The team responsible for the game listen to feedback from the players, and the game has been updated a couple of times; the errors are slowly getting ironed out, but the game is still highly playable as is it. If you've enjoyed any of AGEOD's previous titles, you'll love this (and know what to expect in terms of game turn resolution time etc.) and it'll be a worthy addition to your wargames library.

reviewText:
A very nice and sucessfull retry at the old Napoleon's Campaign. Technically, it's a good performance : the graphics are nice and the game is smotth and fast enougth despite the many units and factions. The content is, as always with Ageod, very historicaly accurate. IA is not that great but the game offers a lot of MP opporunities. The learning curve is a bit steep and a beginer with WeGo wargame should maybe start with an easier AGE game (Rise of Prussia, Civil War).

+ Historical Accuracy
+ 10 years imperial campaign
+ 6+ players campaign
+ Rather good IA...

- ... but still not challenging enough for Grognards!
- Not enougth short scenarios
